section.title: Reflections
section.p: When we decompose matrices into products of other matrices, we often wish to create matrices with many zero entries. A Householder matrix is a unitary matrix which transforms a vector into a vector of the same size that is a nonzero multiple of the first column of an identity matrix, thus creating a vector with just a single nonzero entry. A typical application is to zero out entries of a matrix below the diagonal, column-by-column, in order to achieve a triangular matrix.

statement.p: Given a nonzero vector \vect{v}\in\complex{n}, the Householder matrix for \vect{v} isP = I_n-\left(\frac{2}{\innerproduct{\vect{v}}{\vect{v}}}\right)\vect{v}\adjoint{\vect{v}}. The vector \vect{v} is called the Householder vector.

section.p: A Householder matrix is both Hermitian and unitary.

statement.p: The Householder matrix for \vect{v}\in\complex{n} is Hermitian.
The Householder matrix for \vect{v}\in\complex{n} is unitary.

section.p: Our aim with a Householder matrix is to convert a vector \vect{x} into a scalar multiple of the first column of the identity matrix, \vect{e}_1. Which Householder vector should we choose for constructing such a matrix, and which multiple will we get? It is an instructive exercise to reverse-engineer the choice by setting P\vect{x}=\alpha\vect{e}_1 (Exercise ). Instead, we give the answer and prove that it does the desired job.

statement.p: Given a vector \vect{x}\in\real{n}, define \vect{v}=\vect{x}\pm\norm{\vect{x}}\vect{e}_1 and let P be the Householder matrix for the Householder vector \vect{v}. Then P\vect{x}=\mp\norm{\vect{x}}\vect{e}_1.

section.p: To be more specific, consider the specific situation of Example , viewed in \real{3}. The hyperplane is the subspace orthogonal to \vect{v}, or the two-dimensional plane with \vect{v} as its normal vector, and equation -5x+4y+7z=0. The points (4,4,7) and (9,0,0) lie on either side of the plane and are a reflection of each other in the plane, by which we mean the vector (4,4,7)-(9,0,0)=(-5,4,7) is perpendicular (orthogonal, normal) to the plane.

Our choice of \vect{v} can be replaced by \vect{v}=\vect{x}+\norm{\vect{x}}\vect{e}_1, so in the previous example we would have \vect{v}=\colvector{13\\4\\7}, and then P would take \vect{x} to \colvector{-9\\0\\0}. This would be a reflection across the plane with equation 13x+4y+7z=0. Notice that the normal vector of this plane is orthogonal to the normal vector of the previous plane, which is not an accident (Exercise ).

As a practical matter, we would choose the Householder vector which moves \vect{x} the furthest, to get better numerical behavior. So in our example above, the second choice would be better, since \vect{x} will be moved a distance 2\norm{\vect{v}} and the second \vect{v} has a larger norm.

statement.p: In the real case, we have two choices for a Householder vector which will zero out most of a vector. Show that these two vectors, \vect{x}+\norm{\vect{x}}\vect{e}_1 and \vect{x}-\norm{\vect{x}}\vect{e}_1, are orthogonal to each other.

Prove the following generalization of Theorem. Given a vector \vect{x}\in\complex{n}, define \rho=\vectorentry{\vect{x}}{1}/\modulus{\vectorentry{\vect{x}}{1}} and \vect{v}=\vect{x}\pm\rho\norm{\vect{x}}\vect{e}_1 and let P be the Householder matrix for the Householder vector \vect{v}. Then P\vect{x}=\mp\rho\norm{\vect{x}}\vect{e}_1.

hint.p: You can establish the same identity as in the first part of the proof of Theorem.

statement.p: Suppose that P is a Householder matrix of size n and \vect{b}\in\complex{n} is any vector. Find an expression for the matrix-vector product P\vect{b} which will suggest a way to compute this vector with fewer than the \orderof{2n^2} operations required for a general matrix-vector product.

Begin with the condition that a Householder matrix will accomplish P\vect{x}=\alpha\vect{e}_1 and discover the choice for the Householder vector described in Theorem . Hint: The condition implies that the Householder vector \vect{v} is in the span of \set{\vect{x}, \vect{e}_1}.
